Organization Name: Organisation pour le Développement Economique et Social (ODES-Bénin ONG)
Organization Mission or One Line Pitch: Description de l'organisation Fournissez une brève description de votre organisation, en vous concentrant sur votre expérience dans la plantation ou la pousse des arbres tout en engageant les communautés locales. Dites-nous ce qui rend votre organisation unique et efficace. (150-400 mots)   Cela peut être identique ou similaire aux informations du « Résumé de l'organisation » que vous avez fournies lors du cycle de candidature initial, mais assurez-vous que votre réponse ici se concentre sur votre expérience antérieure dans la restauration des terres. En 1998, un groupe de jeune Béninois, après une analyse profonde des stratégies d’intervention des organismes de développement dans le nord dans le domaine du développement rural, s’est vu dans l’obligation de mettre en place une organisation de développement qui pourrait se consacrer essentiellement à la formation paysanne pour une souveraineté alimentaire durable des populations rurales du nord-ouest du Bénin. Enregistré officiellement en 2000, des actions d’appui aux itinéraire techniques de production ont l’amélioration des rendements agricoles et des superficies emblavées et du coup une amélioration de la sécurité alimentaire des populations. Ces dernières année plusieurs études ont démontré qu’en dehors de la production cotonnière, l’élevage bovin essentiellement extensif et transhumant, l’exploitation forestière abusive, les feux de végétation, les influences climatiques sahéliennes sont autant d’autres facteurs qui exercent des pressions sur les terres et la végétation dans notre zone d’intervention. ODES Bénin a alors accentué ces dernières année ses actions sur la lutte contre ces facteurs et la mise en œuvre des actions de reboisement. Une ferme sylvoagropastoral de 20 ha a été installée à Tanguiéta au nord-ouest du Bénin et sert essentiellement à la production de plants. Ainsi en trois ans, 420ha ont été reboisés avec l’appui financier de nos différents partenaires.
ENFORAC aims to continually find ways that enable communities to live sustainably, by collaborating to conserve Protected Areas and Critical Ecosystems.
We are committed to sustainably improve the well-being of poorest people of Rwanda using community-based approach to find solutions to livelihoods and environmental challenges

Organization Name: The Jane Goodall Institute for Wildlife Research, Education and Conservation (Uganda)
Organization Mission or One Line Pitch: The Jane Goodall Institute (JGI) is an international conservation organization that is legally registered with the Uganda Non-Governmental Organization (NGO) Board and has worked since 1991 to increase capacity of government and forest adjacent communities to manage protected areas and engage in natural resource management.  JGI-Uganda focuses on 22 tropical rain forests located in the Albertine Rift. JGI-Uganda implements conservation projects in Budongo-Bugoma Corridor (BBC) to create corridor connectivity for wildlife and build healthy habitat. We have worked with the National Forestry Authority (NFA) and forest adjacent communities to ensure regeneration of forests on forest reserves and remaining patches of community and privately-owned lands in the BBC.    JGI-Uganda has conducted massive community reforestation efforts mainly in forests outside protected areas in the BBC. In the last five years, we planted over three million trees to restore degraded and/or depleted forests and vital corridors that connect communities of chimpanzees, improving long-term genetic viability of the species across its range.  As JGI-Uganda seeks to re-establish connectivity between the two central forest reserves of Budongo and Bugoma by replanting degraded riparian forests spanning 34 km of community-owned land, the riparian forest degradation has resulted in loss of critical corridor for wildlife migration and siltation of rivers with attendant reduction in water quality and quantity (JGI 2010). These forests have an estimated 680 and 570 chimpanzees respectively. The corridors connecting these forests have an estimated 250-350 chimpanzees.  We contend that communities adjacent to a forest will protect that forest when social and economic benefits equal or overweigh benefits of forest clearance. JGI-Uganda supports target communities in growing select trees and links them to markets to enhance their incomes in addition to livelihood interventions provided by other projects.

Organization Name: Action d'aide Humanitaire pour le Développement (AHD)
Organization Mission or One Line Pitch: Créée depuis le 04 Novembre 2000, l’ONG AHD compte aujourd’hui plus de 20ans d’expériences dans le reboisement et la restauration des écosystèmes forestiers et des mangroves en particulier avec la mise en œuvre des projets tels que: la Restauration 04ha de la mangrove lagunaire dans le canton d'Agouègan ainsi que la mise en place d’une forêt communautaire d’acacia de 05ha financé par PNUD/FEM (2012-2014) ; la Restauration de 12ha de la mangrove dans les villages de Klouvidonnou, Agokpamè et Zébé, et d'une plantation communautaire de rônier sur 05ha à  Agokpamè avec la Banque Mondiale/PGICT  (2015-2017); le Reboisement linéaire de 3ha de la berge dans le cantond’agbodrafo avec les propagules de palétuvier rouge (2016-2018) financé par le PNUD; la réalisation de la cartographie de la zone à mangrove du Sud-Ouest du Togo financé par France-Volontaire/Projet AVENIR (2020) ; Reboisement de 05ha de forêt communautaire à Matchalé (commune d’Afagnan  (2019); la mise en défends et le reboisement de 03hectares de rive dans la Préfecture de VO financée par le FAO/Togo(2020) ; Restauration de 20ha de mangrove le long du chenal Gbaga dans le cadre de la mise en œuvre du projet WACA-ResIP (2020-2023) ; la Restauration et la mise en défends de 50ha de berge avec les pieds de palétuviers rouge et blanc à Agbodankopé avec la financement de WACA-FFEM (2021-2024); la Restauration de 15ha de berge à Togokomè financé par UICN (2021-2023); Renforcement de la résilience de la rivière Zio par la restauration de ses berges dans les communes de Zio1 et d’Agoenyivé 4 financé par WACA-Résip/bis (2021-2023). Ce qui rend notre organisation unique et efficace, c’est la mise en place dans chaque village et sur chaque projet des cellules de surveillance dont les membres sont chargés de mise en œuvre des actions sur le terrain et de la pérennisation des acquis.

Kikandwa Environmental Association (KEA) is a Community Based development organization founded in 1999 with a purpose of addressing rural development issues and natural resources management.  KEA was born out of the need to address the alarming low levels of agricultural productivity, high level of food insecurity, low income in the rural communities in addition to protecting natural resources against rapid degradation in Mityana district

DREK aims to manage the environmental impacts of the deterioration of the environment and the natural resource base due to deforestation, degradation of grazing lands, competition for pasture, loss of wildlife, soil erosion, open disposal of solid waste (especially plastics), and uncontrolled abstraction of groundwater. DREK supports environmental and natural resource restorative measures that rehabilitate and improve the productivity of the natural resources and support other productive systems such as irrigated agriculture, access to water for humans and livestock, pasture development, including value addition for livestock and agricultural products.  DREK has in the past partnered with the County Government and collaborated with other organizations with objectives of environmental conservation and restoration of degraded lands. Key activities have included natural regeneration, enrichment tree planting, tree planting in institutions.  The organization has collaborated with organizations such as UNHCR, FaIDA, RRDO, Red Cross and KDRDIP to address impacts of prolonged presence of refugees in Fafi, Lagdera, Wajir South and Dadaab. DREK currently has partnered with Fafi Integrated Development Association implementing the World Bank Project, Kenya Development Response to Displacement Impacts Project (KDRDIP) whose objective is to improve access to basic social services, expand economic opportunities, and enhance environmental management for communities hosting refugees in the target areas of Kenya.  The interventions include rehabilitation of degraded sites, agro-forestry, management of solid wastes and provision of alternative energy sources such as solar, wind, and provision of access to improved and energy-saving devices. DREK avails information on site species matching to optimize on the survival of trees and establishment of forests, the species site matching guidelines is updated and availed to the public.  www.dre-kenya.org

Action Le Vert est une ONG de droit Congolais créée en 2001 en République Démocratique du Congo,  Son siège est situé à Bukavu. Domaines d’interventions :  L'environnement Reboisement  Restauration des terres dégradées  Améliorer l'agriculture  Lutte anti-érosion  Vulgarisation des foyers améliorés pour réduire la consommation de bois afin de protéger nos forêts Sa mission est de promouvoir et protéger la biodiversité en restaurant les écosystèmes. Sa Vision : Amener la population congolaise en général et celle de l'Est du pays en particulier à vivre dans un environnement sain pour un développement durable.  But : Protéger l'environnement écologique et restaurer les écosystèmes dégradés. Ses activités :  Sensibiliser et former la population locale sur la désertification, la dégradation des terres et le changement climatique. Reboiser les collines dénudées et former des paysages verts ; Restaurer et fertiliser les terres agricoles pour augmenter la production agricole ; Promouvoir les économies d'énergie en vulgarisant les foyers améliorés afin de réduire la déforestation ; Former les femmes et les jeunes à l'agro-industrie pour lutter contre la pauvreté ; Regrouper les producteurs locaux en coopératives agricoles et promouvoir l'économie rurale  Renforcement des capacités dans les nouvelles techniques de culturales. Intégrer les arbres d’agroforesterie dans les champs des cultures vivrières des communautés.  Aménager les dispositifs antiérosifs à travers des haies  suivant les courbes du niveau. Promouvoir l’élevage pour la production du fumier : Malgré les interventions d’autres acteurs dans le domaine, Action Le Vert à la spécificité de se concentrer autour des aires protégées PNKB et RNI) pour réduire la déforestation à travers l’introduction de l’agriculture climato-sensible et la promotion de l’économie de l’énergie aux populations riveraines.

We provide Forest Dependent Households (FDHs) with clean cookstoves, wood pellets and tree seedlings. The clean cookstove replaces traditional polluting stoves while the wood pellets, replaces firewood and charcoal that causes alarming deforestations and degradations. Then each family also receives and plants trees. The communities are trained on reforestation, agroforestry, sustainable management of forests, and enhancement of forest carbon stocks. For this Project, 2,000 hectares of existing forest would be protected using REDD+, 70 hectares will be restored and 5,000 households will receive Powerstove cookstoves and wood pellets to stop deforestation and forests degradations for charcoal and firewood for cooking, thereby protecting the forests. The Project aligns with ongoing livelihood and forest protection activities and carbon saved from REDD+ and cookstoves, will be sold to companies that want to achieve carbon reduction and help finance the continuation of the Project to Year 5. We have secured Purchase Agreements from buyers for such carbon offsets. Communities will receive revenue from sale of carbon offsets to develop community projects, pay forest guards and labor for maintenance of the trees to reach maturity by Year 5. Also, each household will be paid $15 quarterly from carbon credits generated from 8,000 tons per year for 20 years from the REDD+ project and 20,000 tons per year for 5 years from the Powerstove cookstove project. We will recruit and train youths from the communities on data gathering using our proprietary IoT and GIS systems to ensure Project sustainability. These data will help in M&E and learning. This will ensure FDHs are provided with cooking alternatives that is cheap, available and adaptable to their cooking lifestyle to ensure that reforestation efforts are not quickly sabotaged by the axes of smallholder farmers’ quest for firewood. Beneficiaries will earn up to $300 in savings annually, which can improve their livelihood.

Indigenous Maasai Climate Adaptation Alliance (IMCAA) is a community based organization (CBO) based in Narok County, Kenya and founded in 2018. The organization works directly with communities and households and is committed to bridging community development gaps through its integrated approach by supporting household activities through climate change adaptation, resilience building, resource mobilization and livelihoods enhancement. MISSION: IMCAA CBO exists to carry out its mission which is:  “Pastoralists, Agro-Pastoralists and other marginalized groups in Narok County area are empowered from negative socio-economic effects of climate change, food insecurity and environmental degradation.” KEY OBJECTIVES 1 To reduce climate change effects to communities in IMCAA operational area through community resilience and adaptation strategies.   2 To increased food security interventions among communities in IMCAA operational area. 3 To enhance environmental conservation within IMCAA operational area. STRATEGIES In pursuit of its aims and objectives, IMCAA CBO will apply various approaches and methodologies that will include:-  1.  Formation of strong social groups 2.  Involvement, participation and empowerment of communities through their working social groups 3. Encouragement of the democratic practices in all transactions and decision making processes 4.  Lobbying  5.  Networking and collaboration CORE VALUES / PRINCIPLES 1. Participation by all 2.  Justice for all 3. Empowerment 4. Dialogue, Peace and social communication 5.  Sustainability

This may be the same or similar to the “Organization Summary” information that you provided in the initial application round, but please make sure that your answer here focuses on your prior experience in restoring land by growing trees and in engaging the community.  Biodiversity Conservation Initiative is a not for profit duly registered trust under the Trustees Incorporation Act of Malawi (TR/INC1746). BCI works with communities to conserve biodiversity.  BCI has been working with rural communities in northern and central Malawi since 2013 focusing on on-farm conservation of agrobiodiversity and sustainable agriculture. Activities done have been establishing woodlots, planting agroforestry trees, establishing orchards, training farmers in sustainable agriculture, soil and water conservation, management of agrobiodiversity, community seed bank practices.   From 2015 – 2019, BCI, Network for Youth Development and Center for Environmental Policy and Advocacy implemented a My Life My Choice project which focused on empowering youth through management of natural resources. Biodiversity Conservation Initiative trained the youth in natural resources management, agroforestry, soil and water conservation. Over 390000 trees were planted on 5000ha. The trees included Senna spp., Faidherbia albida, Albizia lebbeck, Cajanus cajan, mango, avocados, Mexican apples, orange and lemons.  BCI has trained over 12000 and 27000 in sustainable agriculture practices with the majority practicing on not less than 0.5ha piece of land. BCI has also contributed to conservation and on-farm management of over 50 plant genetic resources to contribute to sustainable use of biodiversity and conservation of agroecosystems.

We mobilize youth and communities to take part in tree planting and natural regeneration management. We work with existing structures which stimulates a sense of ownership and sustainability. Our uniqueness is that we are 100% youth-led and we engage a lot of youth who are energetic and view tree planting as a long term investment, we work within beneficiary communities and are socially connected

Hen Mpoano (Our Coast) is a Ghanaian Non-Governmental Organization (NGO) established to provide technical, policy and extension support to coastal communities to promote and sustain integrated management of coastal and marine ecosystems in Ghana. Hen Mpoano has a decade of experience working to improve coastal and fisheries governance in Ghana. This includes receiving and managing funds directly and indirectly, from the EU, USAID, IUCN, United States Forest Service, Critical Ecosystem Partnership Facility, World Resources Institute, US National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), Shark Foundation among others. Currently, Hen Mpoano is leading the implementation of a project awarded by the WRI to strengthen monitoring of over 180 square kilometers of forest reserves in Ghana, using the Global Forest Watch platform and its GLAD alert system. Hen Mpoano staff provide collective skills and experience in policy advocacy, technical skills in fisheries co-management, forest landscape restoration GIS/remote sensing applications, integrated land use and spatial planning, gender mainstreaming, training and outreach and coastal climate change resilience building. Additional, Hen Mpoano has facilitated the formation and establishment of more than 64 village savings and loan associations within the coastal landscapes of Ghana. These associations provide an effective platform for mobilizing community members for conservation and landscape restoration. Within the Coastal landscapes program area, Hen Mpoano is working as a long-term partner with the United States Forest Service to develop and implement co-management plan for conservation of the Greater Amanzule Wetlands in south- western Ghana. This work has led to the establishment of twenty-five community wetland conservation committees in communities to sustainably manage more than 50,000 hectares of wetland resources. Through this work, more than 900,000 seedlings of mangroves have been raised in three community managed nurseries and replanted.  Furthermore, three Permanent Sampling Plots (PSP) have also been established in replanted mangrove sites to estimate growth rate and assess mangrove ecosystem health. Promotion of Bee keeping and honey production and organic vegetable production as incentive for mangrove forest conservation have also been piloted in wetland-fringe communities.

Trees for the Future (TREES) is currently working with thousands of farming families across nine countries in sub-Saharan Africa. Over our 30+ year history, we’ve worked around the globe. In 2014, we focused our work in select African countries, where the climatic and economic challenges were most pressing and we could make the greatest impact.

Organization Name: Appui pour la protection de l'environnement et le developpement (APED)
Organization Mission or One Line Pitch: APED est une organisation de la société civile camerounaise qui travaille dans la perspective selon laquelle la gestion durable des terres et des forêts constitue un facteur de développement important des régions et des populations des zones forestières.  Depuis sa création APED en collaboration avec l’Etat camerounais, ICRAF et WWF accompagne avec succès les populations locales et autochtones de la zone Kribi Campo Ma’an dans la valorisation des produits forestiers non ligneux à travers l’agroforesterie. Ce qui nous a permis de former les communautés sur  les techniques de multiplication végétatives des arbres agroforstiers, la mise en place des champs écoles, le developpement des pépinières, le planting, les ventes groupées, la dynamique de groupe, la prévention et la gestion des conflits ainsi que la gestion financière. Ces activités sont menées de façon participative avec les communautés prenant en compte les spécificités des femmes et des autochtones Bagyélis dans la mise en œuvre des activités réalisées. A ceci s’ajoute le choix participatif des arbres agroforestiers qui se fait via des critères tels que l’aspect de rentabilité économique, sociale et environnemental de l’arbre.  Ce qui rend notre organisation unique et efficace ; APED est implanté dans la zone du projet depuis un peu plus de 17 ans et jouit d’une confiance auprès des communautés car connaissant parfaitement le milieu, les besoins et les aspirations de celles-ci. A ce jour tous les projets agroforestiers réalisés sont suivis à travers des outils de proximités développées par APED qui permettent de connaitre et de documenter au quotidien l’évolution des arbres de la pépinière jusqu’à la production/vente. A côté de ceci APED dispose des partenaires mondialement reconnus sur les questions d’agroforesterie à l’instar de ICRAF qui en fonction des objectifs agroforestiers visé organise des séances de recyclages en direction des équipes APED sur les nouvelles techniques agroforestières.

KTL’s mission is to become a reputable and well-funded organization which works harmoniously with strategic partners; has an effective and efficient governance system and develops, manages and sustainably achieves its vision.

Organization Name: ACTION COMMUNAUTAIRE POUR LE DEVELOPPEMENT DURABLE (ACDD)
Organization Mission or One Line Pitch: Action Communautaire pour le Développement Durable (ACDD) est une organisation à but non lucratif qui œuvre  pour le développement durable des communautés à travers des actions multisectorielles, participatives et citoyennes visant l’autonomisation socio-économique des jeunes,  de la femme et des personnes vulnérables ; la résilience communautaire et la mitigation des effets du réchauffement globale ; la préservation et la restauration de la biodiversité ; l’amélioration des conditions de vie des communautés, la promotion de l’entreprenariat et la création de l’emploi. ACDD œuvre pour réduire la contribution humaine au réchauffement globale, pour limiter les effets des perturbations climatiques sur les populations vulnérables et accroitre la capacité d’adaptation des communautés aux effets du réchauffement globale en participant à la conservation et à la restauration de la biodiversité globale, en assurant une utilisation durable des ressources naturelles et en faisant l’accompagnement des communautés vers des modes de vie durables. ACDD agit simultanément sur deux leviers pour faire face au réchauffement globale en priorisant la participation communautaire dans la mise en œuvre des interventions : (1) d’une part elle intervient dans gestion durable des ressources naturelles par le renforcement des capacités  et la sensibilisation des communautés ; la vulgarisation et la mise en œuvre des pratiques agricoles durables, des techniques de cuisson et de production de charbon éco responsables ; la gestion des déchets et la promotion des énergies vertes. (2) d’autre part ACDD œuvre dans l’atténuation et la mitigation des effets du réchauffement globale par des campagnes de multiplication et de plantations d’arbres grâce à des pépinières communautaires, la lutte anti érosive intégrée, l’aménagement paysager   et la restauration des écosystèmes.

MAPTO est créé le 20 Août 2003 par un groupe de 205 paysans issus des différentes préfectures du pays. Avec plus de 23000 membres aujourd’hui, l’organisation est structurée depuis la base qui est le village en coopératives, puis en unions de coopératives au niveau cantonal et préfectoral. En région (ensemble de préfectures), un comité régional dirigé par le délégué régional anime la vie du mouvement.  Depuis 2012, MAPTO s’est engagé dans la promotion des pratiques agro écologiques : l’agroforesterie, le reboisement et l’organisation des pépiniéristes. Pour l’agroforesterie: mise en place de comités cantonaux de réflexion de proposer des actions locales de gestion des ressources naturelles et de la mobilité des animaux.    Depuis Juillet 2019, pour 36 mois, MAPTO assure en consortium avec deux Organisations Non Gouvernementales, la mise en œuvre du projet de « Promotion des Exploitations Familiales Agro écologiques productrices de maïs et de soja pour des Revenus Durables dans la région des Plateaux au Togo (PEFARD:régénération naturelle assistée, agroforesterie, compost, plantes fertilisantes, association soja maïs), mise en place des cadres villageois de concertation multi acteurs et les comités de veille et d’alerte en gestion des ressources naturelles. Une autre expérience dans la plantation des arbres est celle développée avec la FAO dans le cadre d’un protocole d’accord dans le cadre du mécanisme FFF pour le renforcement organisationnel de trois coopératives : aménagement et renforcement en capacités de production des plants des pépiniéristes, accompagnement pour la plantation de dix mille plants pour des membres d’OPFA. Ce qui rend MAPTO unique et efficace se trouve dans ses origines car étant une initiative endogène des paysans eux-mêmes. MAPTO a une forte expérience en mobilisation paysanne en travaillant directement avec les coopératives dans les villages et l’implication des autorités locales.

Organization Name: Women in Water and Natural Resources Conservation (WWANC)
Organization Mission or One Line Pitch: WWANC envisions a world where communities and ecosystems are resilient in the face of climate change. Together with like-minded partners globally invest in empowering frontline community groups (women groups) so that they can manage climate shocks, rebound and continue on a progressive pathway to sustainable development. We incorporate in this work lenses on environmental justice, equity, and strive for community-first solutions. Since 2019 WWANC and Women’s Earth Alliance (WEA) have been working on a similar project, women accelerators for community climate Resilience in Nine counties in Kenya (Kakamega, Nakuru, Narok, Mt Elgon, Homabay, Busia, Taita Taveta and Uasin Gishu) through local adaptation actions and initiatives within a whole society approach by creating women climate centers and hubs that address poverty and inequality in the area of conservation, ecosystem degradation and biodiversity loss and catastrophic climate change. The project has successful led to an increase of forest cover in the mentioned counties with over 50,000 indigenous trees planted, 50, tree nurseries established across the country, 50 energies saving jikos, installed at household level, promotion of fruit tree as alternative livelihoods in Kakamega forest in partnership with International Tree Foundation and over a 20,000 population having benefited from the Community climate Resilience trainings and tree planting initiatives as a community based  adaptation actions implemented by WWANC in partnership with like minded stakeholders  .  WWANC plays a key role in community conservation advocacy influencing the County Assemblies in drafting Environmental, Water, forestry & Natural Resources legislation. WWANC in collaboration with the Kakamega County, participate in annual national tree planting campaigns to help the country attain 10% forest cover. WWANC partners with other international organizations such as; Global Green grants Fund-(UK), Women Climate Centers International(WCCI)

NCF pursues the conservation of nature and its resources with the aim of improving the quality of human life both in the present and the future by: Conserving the full range of Nigeria’s biodiversity, this includes species, ecosystems, and genetic biodiversity; Promoting the sustainable use of natural resources for the benefit and well-being of the present and future generations of Nigerians and Undertake field programmes and advocacy to promote best practices in climate change adaptation and mitigation, minimize pollution, as well as reduce wasteful utilization of renewable resources.

ABPL is a social impact not for profit company limited by guarantee. It was formally registered in Kenya in 2021, but has been in operation as Kenya Biogas Program (KBP), a national program under Hivos foundation since 2015. ABPL over the last 6 years has focused on access to clean cooking energy for households, land restoration and agricultural productivity interventions. ABPL has reached over 23,000 households across the country, now using biogas for cooking as opposed to the traditional fuels predominantly firewood and charcoal. With biodigester intervention, we have saved 58,907 hectares of forests from deforestation and influenced application of 481,964 t(DM)of bioslurry which is organic fertilizer from the biodigester digestate.  The farming households we support are all trained twice annually on the management and application of the bio fertilizer from their biodigesters to different value chains, which include; fruit trees, coffee and tea bushes, vegetables , fodder crops and other staples including maize and legumes. ABPL is unique in the sense that we are organizing households that are using biodigesters into bioenergy user enterprises (BUEs). This stems from the biogas marketing hub model, which we have applied since 2016. Biogas marketing hubs (BMHs) are farmer organizations in form of cooperatives, SACCOs, and MFIs whom we have partnered with, with an agreement to train and link them to our field extension service providers and quality technicians to enable them offer clean cooking solutions to their members as we both deliver on the universal energy access agenda. Currently we are signed up with over 25 farmer organizations across the country. ABPL’s move to establish the Bioenergy User Enterprises (BUEs) seeks to involve the many other farmers who may not belong to the 25 marketing hubs we have partnered with. This project gives us an opportunity to establish the initial BUEs around Agroforestry enterprises anchored on energy access.

Organization Name: Society for the Conservation of Nature of Liberia (SCNL)
Organization Mission or One Line Pitch: To educate, encourage and assist the public to understand the need to conserve nature, build consensus on the effective management of biodiversity, and to ensure that the use of natural resources is sustainable.

JVE BENIN se fixe comme mission de Soutenir et de renforcer les capacités des acteurs aux différents échelons, en particulier les femmes et les jeunes afin de les rendre résilients et capables de jouer efficacement leur rôle dans la sauvegarde de leur Cadre de Vie.

Organization Name: ONG des Guides d’Andasibe ( ONG GA)
Organization Mission or One Line Pitch: L’ONG des Guides d’Andasibe est un organisme local à but non lucratif, crée en 2015 dont le siège social est à Andasibe dans la partie Orientale de Madagascar. L’organisme a plusieurs années d’expériences sur les activités liées à la conservation de la biodiversité, la promotion des activités d’amélioration de niveau de vie, ainsi que et la mobilisation communautaire. Depuis 2019, avec le projet SOS Lemurs auquel financé l’UICN, l’organisme s’est focalisé sur la  restauration de la forêt de Mahatsara en collaboration avec la communauté locale. Deux sites de pépinière communautaire ont été installés et 6 communautés locales ont été engagées de manière permanente et ont été formés pour assurer la production des jeunes. Le choix de l’espèce à produire s’est focalisé sur leurs fonctions, leurs utilités et leur degré de pression auxquelles les espèces ont subi. La plupart des espèces produites dans les pépinières sont parmi les espèces de plante consommés et utilisés par les lémuriens. Jusqu’à présent,  28.000 jeunes plants issus de 79 espèces autochtones ont été mis en terre pour restaurer une surface de 18ha dans les habitats défrisés.La mise en terre et le suivi de la plantation sont totalement assurés périodiquement par les communautés locales. Au total, au moins 300 communautés ont pu bénéficier directement à l’activité de restauration.   Grace au climat humide de la zone de Mahatsara, le taux de survie des jeunes plants est de de 94 %. L’AGA adopte pour toutes ces activités une approche participative et collaborative. Les plans d’action et les réalisations sont présentés et validés par les membres de bureau du VOI. Ainsi, 80 % des personnes travaillant au projet provient de la communauté laquelle on travaille.

Organization Name: Green to Abundance Development and Empowerment Foundation (GADEF)
Organization Mission or One Line Pitch: GADEF has existed since 2018 (official registration, though started work prior to registration) to promote growing of endangered indigenous tree species in our part of South-Western Nigeria. Based in Ado-Ekiti, it is led by  silviculturalists and foresters with long experience in public service. We work with individuals, communities, schools and NGO partners to promote tree growing, and to explore means of protecting our rare indigenous tree species through in-situ and ex-situ conservation, propagation and reforestation. We operate our own nursery which is also used to train students  in practical silviculture.   Please see attached document for an overview. What makes us unique is our concentration on indigenous species as keystone of environmental restoration – almost all other restoration efforts in Nigeria have used imported exotics or monocultures to meet these ends. What makes us effective is that we are not only experienced in silviculture and in public service, but we are well-networked and rooted in the local context. Therefore, we achieve our goals by leveraging two strong aspects of Ekiti culture - the culture of community pride and collective endeavour in our State, evident in communal decision-making and traditional leadership institutions; and the self-image as a ‘progressive’ people who embrace social advancement through education and innovation. We feel that our community-managed, indigenous-species-led model has high potential for replicability elsewhere.   In the last year, we gained additional experience in larger-scale land restoration as technical partner in the World Bank-funded Ekiti State NEWMAP project, which planted 250ha of exotic and indigenous tree species (many of the seedlings raised by GADEF) to combat water erosion. We have also had input into the Ekiti State Forest Roadmap – prepared on behalf of the State Government by a local NGO with backing from US charity EIA. Our views and those of other stakeholders are reflected in it

L’ONG JVE s’est assignée pour mission de développer le leadership et l’écocitoyenneté des jeunes en vue de leur implication dans la promotion du développement durable des communautés. Elle a pour Vision de participer à la construction d'un monde où les communautés sont épanouies, et où les jeunes sont à l’avant-garde du développement durable. Comme Valeurs fondamentales, JVE se préoccupe du mieux-être de la jeunesse et de la justice sociale pour tous. Elle promeut la participation des jeunes au développement durable. Volontariat, Responsabilité, Intégrité écologique, Excellence, Justice et Equité Diversité fondent les interventions de JVE. Son but consiste à aider la jeunesse à s’épanouir tout en participant au Développement Durable dans tous ses aspects. Elle intervient dans les domaines de la conservation de la Biodiversité, de l’Eau et l’Assainissement, de l’Energie, du Changement Climatique puis du développement local et communautaire à travers trois (3) axes définis par son plan d’action périodique : Axe 1 : Energie-Climat et développement ; Axe 2 : Gestion Durable des Ressources Naturelles, Axe 3 : Engagement Eco citoyen.  Les principaux objectifs de JVE sont: protéger et explorer l’héritage naturel; Promouvoir l’esprit de volontariat et entrepreneuriat vert; Impliquer toutes les couches sociales dans la protection du cadre de vie; Faciliter l’accès aux ressources naturelles ; Défendre et protéger les droits et intérêts des paysans et des groupes à risque ; participer à la réduction, de la pauvreté tout en veillant à la sauvegarde de l’environnement

KADEC has vast experience in implementing programmes that promote land restoration via tree planting. Through the “Enhancement of Participatory Water Resource Management (EPWM) Project, KADEC has been promoting environmental recovery through tree planting in degraded areas such as Giliya, Kalambo, Mwambuli, Miyombo and Kenani villages, and in schools such as Lupaso, Mpata, Silu, Lulindo, St.Annes, Lemero, Baka  and Ngerenge, and along the rivers  such as  Makeghe, Wayi and  North Rukulu. The interventions under the EPWM project included awareness campaign to enhance community based participatory water resource management and promotion of environmental recovery through tree planting. As a result of this project, many communities have actively empowered in forest conservation, management and utilisation.  KADEC under Sustainable Forest Management Project (SFMP) has managed to facilitate the planting of 1,230,000 multi- purpose trees under village forest areas and 9, 000 fruits and shade trees under primary and secondary schools. The interventions under SFMP included awareness forums for the communities on forest conservation and protection, formation of and training of School Environmental Clubs (SECCs), Village Natural Resource Committees (VNRMCs) and encourage the rights of communities and individual tree growers to forestry management.  Planting and growing fruits and shades tree species is an on-going environmental programme that is instigated by KADEC as a means of conserving the environment with particular emphasis to schools and the communities around them. Therefore,  KADEC is well placed to deliver this project, having previously implemented similar projects in schools and communities in Malawi successfully.

Organization Name: African Research Association managing Development in Nigeria (ARADIN)
Organization Mission or One Line Pitch: ARADIN is a Non-Government Organization (NGO) in Nigeria registered with the Corporate Affairs Commission according to the Company and Allied Matters Act 1990. With the Mission to work in partnership with rural communities to promote conservation and sustainable livelihoods, ARADIN has worked with rural communities in the entire landscape of Cross River State; mostly forest-dependent communities promoting and adapting global good practices to local realities in the effort to conserve nature and improve the livelihoods and wellbeing of these communities. This fulfils ARADIN’s Goal and Objectives, which are achieved through a robust and holistic programming with strategic focus on community forestry, sustainable livelihoods, participatory governance, research and policy, climate change mitigation and adaptation and an array of cross-cutting themes with strong emphasis on gender, equity, and education. ARADIN’s primary target groups are the marginalized groups in communities, specifically women and youths. ARADIN has over 25 years of practical experience in managing small, medium and large-scale projects directly applied to rural community development with comparatively low overheads. ARADIN is a member of Global Environment Facility (GEF) CSO network, Budget, Transparency and Accountability Network (BTAN), Non-governmental Organizations Coalition for the Environment (NGOCE), Federal Ministry of Environment NGOs, Climate and Sustainable Development Network of Nigeria.

Organization Name: Action d'aide Humanitaire pour le Développement (AHD)
Organization Mission or One Line Pitch: Créée depuis le 04 Novembre 2000, l’ONG AHD compte aujourd’hui plus de 20ans d’expériences dans le reboisement et la restauration des écosystèmes forestiers et des mangroves en particulier avec la mise en œuvre des projets tels que: la Restauration 04ha de la mangrove lagunaire dans le canton d'Agouègan ainsi que la mise en place d’une forêt communautaire d’acacia de 05ha financé par PNUD/FEM (2012-2014) ; la Restauration de 12ha de la mangrove dans les villages de Klouvidonnou, Agokpamè et Zébé, et d'une plantation communautaire de rônier sur 05ha à  Agokpamè avec la Banque Mondiale/PGICT  (2015-2017); le Reboisement linéaire de 3ha de la berge dans le canton d’agbodrafo avec les propagules de palétuvier rouge (2016-2018) financé par le PNUD; la réalisation de la cartographie de la zone à mangrove du Sud-Ouest du Togo financé par France-Volontaire/Projet AVENIR (2020) ; Reboisement de 05ha de forêt communautaire à Matchalé (commune d’Afagnan  (2019); la mise en défends et le reboisement de 03hectares de rive dans la Préfecture de VO financée par le FAO/Togo(2020) ; Restauration de 20ha de mangrove le long du chenal Gbaga dans le cadre de la mise en œuvre du projet WACA-ResIP (2020-2023) ; la Restauration et la mise en défends de 50ha de berge avec les pieds de palétuviers rouge et blanc à Agbodankopé avec la financement de WACA-FFEM (2021-2024); la Restauration de 15ha de berge à Togokomè financé par UICN (2021-2023); Renforcement de la résilience de la rivière Zio par la restauration de ses berges dans les communes de Zio1 et d’Agoenyivé 4 financé par WACA-Résip/bis (2021-2023). Ce qui rend notre organisation unique et efficace, c’est la mise en place dans chaque village et sur chaque projet des cellules de surveillance dont les membres sont chargés de mise en œuvre des actions sur le terrain et de la pérennisation des acquis.

SUNARMA’s mission is to empower communities to sustainably manage natural resources. To realize its mission, it has the strategies to building technical & institutional capacities of local partners to protect, develop and utilize natural resources and improve livelihoods. Since its inception, it has achieved sustainable forest management in various parts of Ethiopia and restoration of degraded forest landscapes through the establishment of Forest Management Cooperatives by engaging target communities in Afforestation/Reforestation, undertake natural regeneration, enrichment planting, Agroforestry practices, Development of woodlots by organizing job less youths. Such actions were achieved through establishing central, group and individual tree nurseries. The above has resulted in reduced deforestation, improved forest conditions and biodiversity, enhanced community forest ownership feeling, decreased forest fire incidence and improved ecosystem services. Our long term experience in PFM in Wof-Washa forest has been scaled up to Highland forests of Gurage, Sidama and Combratum –terminalia woodland in North West Amhara.

Organization Name: Multipurpose Training and Community Empowerment Association ( MTCEA)
Organization Mission or One Line Pitch: To work in a holistic manner towards improvement in the quality of life through interventions that reduce vulnerability from illiteracy, poverty, disease, hunger and environment degradation.

The GSA is a multi-stakeholder platform with 706 members from 36 countries representing all shea stakeholder groups including women’s cooperatives, international oils and fat suppliers, and leading food and cosmetic brands. Through public private partnerships, the GSA promotes industry sustainability, quality practices and standards, and demand for shea in food and cosmetic products.  The GSA has a unique approach to land restoration through public-private partnerships to ensure that restoration brings increased incomes to shea communities. The GSA has the following experience in terms of land restoration and tree planting:  • USAID Sustainable Shea Initiative (2016-2024): this PPP project across West Africa includes a matching fund component for private sector companies to undertake, among other things, tree planting and parkland management trainings in the communities in which they source from. • EU Developing a Resilient Agroforestry Shea Farm Model (2021-2022): this EUR 0.2m research project seeks to develop an integrated resilient farm system with shea and food crops in Nigeria and document its environmental and economic impact for upscaling. • Ghana Shea Landscape Emission Reductions Project (2021-2028): this $54m project funded by the Green Climate Fund, the Government of Ghana and GSA members seeks to address the alarming deforestation and forest degradation challenges in the Northern Savannah Zone of Ghana, whilst promoting investments in the shea value chain and women’s empowerment. While the project implementation is led by the Ghana Forestry Commission, the GSA acts as a Responsible Party for the implementation of the shea component including: planting of 2.15m shea and native trees, training of 20,000 women shea collectors, and facilitation of $9m private sector investment in the project. • Action for Shea Parklands (2020-2030): an industry-wide initiative to mobilize industry stakeholders to promote, protect and restore shea parklands across Africa.

Organization Name: African Research Association Managing Development In Nigeria (ARADIN)
Organization Mission or One Line Pitch: ARADIN strives to work in partnership with local communities to promote conservation and sustainable livelihoods. Working together with community partners, we aim to bring a lasting difference through the sustainable management of natural resources and promoting sustainable livelihoods through micro enterprise development.

Organization Name: Farm Forestry Smallholder Producers Association of Kenya (FF-SPAK)
Organization Mission or One Line Pitch: Farm Forestry Smallholder Producers Association of Kenya (FF-SPAK) is an apex umbrella producer’s organization based in Nairobi, Kenya and working with farmer groups in Kenya to promote and champion the interests of farm forestry smallholders. It was registered in 2013 with the registrar of Societies. The organization has a head office in Nairobi.  Some of our affiliate members are also in turn made up of local Common Interest Groups (CIGs).    FF-SPAK has a national board of six members made up of elected farmer representatives that provides oversight for the organizations work. The board also plays a very active role in lobby and advocacy on issues affecting members. On the other hand, FF-SPAK has a secretariat led by a chief Executive Officer and a team of 8 technical staff. The secretariat is responsible for providing services to affiliate organizations and does this mainly through projects. FF-SPAK has built a strong reputation for our strong footprint working through our affiliate members and for our national appeal as a professionally run membership institution. Some of the partners we work with include Food and Agriculture Organization’s (FAO) Forest and Farm Facility.   More than 4,000 hectares have been reforested so far under the landscape restoration component of this project. Another partner is Forest and Food Development Finland (FFD) that has funded a project that has a component of restoration through supporting tree nurseries. FF-SPAK is also currently partnering with the United Nations Development Program (UNDP) to support the planting of 1 million trees by supporting youth led tree nurseries across 6 Counties (mostly targeting the coastal counties). This is being done under the Green Economy Youth Activation Program (GrEYAP). Other partners working with FF-SPAK include WeEffect, Mennonite Development Associates (MEDA), and Forest Action Network, among others.

Organization Name: Action pour la Protection de l’Environnement et la Promotion des Filieres Agricoles «APEFA»
Organization Mission or One Line Pitch: APEFA is a National Non-Government Organization founded by people concerned with environment degradation in Rwanda and food security with special focus in the sector of Environment and Natural resources and particularly the area of Forestry, Sustainable Land Management (SLM) and Land Husbandry technologies, Integrated Soil Fertility Management, as well as improved Integrated Water Resources Management IWRM interventions The organization has over 20 years proven experience in implementation of rural climate resilient projects to improve ecosystem functioning and livelihoods of the most vulnerable communities across Rwanda some of similar assignments implemented by APEFA are :(1). Forest management In Kayonza (789 Ha),Nyagatare (1293 Ha) and Gishwati (774 Ha) funded by RNRA , (2)Sebeya river bank protection and its tributaries with agroforestry trees plantation, bamboo plantation in Rubavu District, Kanama Sector, (3) Reducing Vulnerability to Climate Change in North West Rwanda through Community Based Adaptation (RV3CBA) Project ( funded by Netherland Embassy ), (4)  Land Husbandry, Water Harvesting and Hillside irrigation/LWH-MINAGRI ( Funded by World Bank), (5) Rehabilitation of Gishwati Nature Forest  in Nyabihu District

MAPTO, dirigé par un conseil d’administration formé de producteurs agricoles, est créé le 20 Août 2003 par un groupe de 205 paysans issus des différentes préfectures du pays. Avec plus de 23000 membres aujourd’hui, l’organisation est structurée depuis la base qui est le village en coopératives, puis en unions de coopératives au niveau cantonal et préfectoral avec des comités cantonaux et préfectoraux. En région (ensemble de préfectures), un comité régional dirigé par le délégué régional anime la vie du mouvement.  Depuis 2012, MAPTO s’est engagé dans la promotion des pratiques agro écologiques : l’agroforesterie, le reboisement et l’organisation des pépiniéristes. Pour l’agroforesterie, nous avions développé l’approche territoire en ciblant les cantons où MAPTO existe : mise en place de comités cantonaux de réflexion de proposer des actions locales de gestion des ressources naturelles et de la transhumance (mobilité des animaux) qui constitue la principale menace des plantations d’arbres dans les champs.    Depuis Juillet 2019, pour 36 mois, MAPTO assure en consortium avec deux Organisations Non Gouvernementales, la mise en œuvre du projet de « Promotion des Exploitations Familiales Agro écologiques productrices de maïs et de soja pour des Revenus Durables dans la région des Plateaux au Togo (PEFARD), soutenu par la CEDEAO et l’AFD dans le cadre du Programme d’Appui à la Transition Agro Ecologique (PATAE). Ce projet a permis d’informer et de former les producteurs de quatre préfectures de la région sur les pratiques agro écologiques (régénérescence assistée, agroforesterie, compost, plantes fertilisantes, association soja maïs), la mise en place des cadres villageois de concertation multi acteurs et les comités de veille et d’alerte en gestion des ressources naturelles. Une autre expérience dans la plantation des arbres est celle développée avec la FAO dans le cadre d’un protocole d’accord dans le cadre du mécanisme FFF pour le renforcement organisationnel de trois coopératives : aménagement et renforcement en capacités de production des plants des pépiniéristes, accompagnement pour la plantation de dix mille plants pour des membres d’OPFA. Ce qui rend MAPTO unique et efficace se trouve dans ses origines car étant une initiative endogène des paysans eux-mêmes. MAPTO a une forte expérience en mobilisation paysanne en travaillant directement avec les coopératives dans les villages et l’implication des autorités locales. A tout ceci s’ajoute l’éventail de partenaires nationaux qui collaborent avec le mouvement dans le cadre de ces activités et pour le développement des actions de terrain.

BRC has served the rural people of he Eastern Cape province for 40 years. (The organisation was established as the "Grahamstown Rural Committee" in 1982). BRC has extensive experience in climate change and forestation. In the past years BRC has planted more than 120ha of pine and cleared more than 150ha of wattle. BRC also has a programme geared at empowering small scale, communal and household farmers towards sustaining their livelihoods through farming, environmentally friendly and agroecological ways of food production, wattle clearing in dams inorder for their livestock to have reliable access to water; and in forestation.

Organization Name: Association Vision des Jeunes Solidaires du Sahel (AVIJESS)
Organization Mission or One Line Pitch: Récépissé de déclaration d’Association n° 033/RDA/K22/SAAJP du 02juin 2017. Le préfet du Département du Diamaré soussigné, conformément à la loi n° 90/053 du 19 décembre 1990 portant sur la liberté d’association, donne à l’Association Vision des Jeunes Solidaires du Sahel (AVIJESS) l’objectifs est de faire le médias et prestation des divers services ; promotion de l’agriculture et l’élevage ; protection de l’environnement (reboisement) ; promotion de développement durable etc. Elle compte actuellement 47 membres dont 32 hommes et 15 femmes. Le but de cette association est de contribuer à l’amélioration de la situation socioéconomique de population. Nous avons plusieurs menée activités consternant les reboisements et la restauration de la terre : o Éducation environnementale dans les écoles primaires, secondaires et les Communautés ;  o Sensibilisation des charbonniers et des agriculteurs sur les abattages illicites des arbres pour la production de charbon végétal et l'agriculture dans les terrains avec déclives ;  o Organiser une campagne de reboisement avec les élèves ainsi que leurs parents respectifs et activités des reboisements et restauration de la terre dans les Communautés etc...

Organization Name: Organization Name: Sustainable Natural Resources Management Association (SUNARMA)
Organization Mission or One Line Pitch: SUNARMA has achieved sustainable forest management in various parts of Ethiopia and restoration of degraded forest landscapes through the establishment of Forest Management Cooperatives by engaging target communities in Afforestation/Reforestation, undertake natural regeneration, enrichment planting, Agroforestry practices, Development of woodlots by organizing job less youths.  SUNARMA has established and supported 11 PFM cooperatives to effectively manage and protect 6,262 hectares of natural Juniper dominated forest in Wof Washa Forest, in the Amhara region of Ethiopia. The project also created 93  enterprises which provide a sustainable source of income for 1,622 people and their household. SUNARMA also successfully set up and supported several cooperatives in The Mount Gurage Integrated Land Management Project (2013-17). It focused on protecting the Afromontane Biteyu forest in the Gurage massif, in particular the conservation of the threatened Podocarpus falcatus through management and natural regeneration of degraded land. The local communities and the government agreed to implement a PFM plan to protect Biteyu forest and ensure it is used sustainably. 700 hectares of forest is now being managed by the PFM cooperatives as a result. In Sidama, Southern Ethiopia we have established 10 PFM cooperatives protecting over 400 Ha. Of natural forest and 10 women Fuel Saving Stoves to reduce deforestation and improve the health & workload of women in collecting fire wood.   In Metema , North West Ethiopia which is one of our flagship project we have established 6 PFM cooperatives closely working with their union protects 50,000Ha. Of forest and we have established over 20 women FSS groups. The project has demonstrated best practice in tapping trees, enhanced the quality and quantity of NTFPs production and introduced behavior change towards land use management and deforestation.
